last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27728749
I feel you. Once you are aware of how much crap is in absolutely everything, there's no going back. It's also hard if you feel you are struggling in life due to not being physically or mentally as good as you maybe should be.
The only advice I can give to you is to try not to worry about what you can't control and focus on making small positive changes in your life to minimize your exposure as much as you can.
Diet is easy. Avoid food that is obviously bad. Try to stick to the outside perimeter of the grocery store as much as you can (meat, eggs, some dairy, fresh fruits and vegetables). Drink mainly water, milk if you enjoy it (personally make homemade kefir).
For water, you can drink RO or distilled. There are some options there for getting that set up in your home. You can use a shower filter. Instead of using a plastic water bottle, try stainless steel or glass. Same for tupperware (most stuff still has plastic lids, just remove them prior to microwaving).
I don't stress about it too much anymore. Life is too short to spend it worrying about shit you (mostly) have no control over. Focus on making your environment and especially your body "safer," that's all you really need.

And yeah I also respect pain-havers. They are ‘awake’, because they are hyper-vigilant and in constant fear. There’s a reason why psychiatric literature claims the depressed and traumatised are more ‘realistic’ than the joyful.

When it comes to ghosting, I do it without meaning to. And it’s not a full ghosting, it’s usually I fail to respond for hours, days, weeks. At some point I recontact when I snap out of it. The closer someone is to me, the less time I am ghosting.

This happens when I dissociate and ‘freeze up’ internally, and hyperfixate on something to numb myself. So, all of reality shuts out. It’s like the people close to me stop existing.

As you can imagine, if someone with BPD dates me (and they have) their abandonment trigger is constantly flaring up just by being around me. Causing them to cling harder and harder. Which was never my intention.

When I was confronted, before I knew of my condition, I would worry the shit out of my loved ones. Either by stonewalling, or abusing alcohol to mask the shame. I was not a saint, even if my BPD ex did damage to me. I did damage to her as well.

Half of my friends have law degrees, it's terrifying. But you just have to accept that some people are better at life than you are and keep chugging. After all, while I know it doesn't feel this way, just know you could be doing SO much worse.

Maybe try doing activities that make you feel good and productive - go on long walks or hikes or runs, spend time with your family, volunteer. Take skill-building classes, learn woodworking or something.

I've felt the same. I got seriously into reading at age 19 and, after spending two years obsessing over the meanings and significances of the world's greatest books while passively doing college work, I found myself at twenty-one 20 lbs heavier with an almost grotesquely disheveled hair and beard structure, while regularly smelling like the underside of someone's ballsack to make matters worse. It felt like I wasted a significant amount of time; as if I crossed a mass gulf of years between my optimistic and dreamy late teenager state and my rancid early 20s experience. No confidence with girls, no vivid career prospects save my growing knowledge of the profession I was studying to work in, and no chance of regaining the skinny physique my body granted me several years ago.

Despite all this, I put my nose back in all my books, and found myself suddenly 28 years old, with a good career and handsome aesthetic qualities such as angular facial features and a good sense of fashion.

My point is that, as long as you are in any way conscientious, the dice will fall in their appropriate spots without you even noticing it all that particularly. If you hyperfixate on the negative sides of your life, such as what you don't have, you'll add unneeded stress into your life, which will sap any energy you'd need to deal with the actual problems in your life consequently.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27724223
>I always feel tired,weighed down, stressed, sore and annoyed
typical depression symptoms
>sore
This is the most concerning one. More noticeable physical symptoms of depression don't usually manifest until after long periods of depression have impacted physical activity (eating habits, sitting on your ass 24/7, self-medication, etc.).
Might be something as simple as a nutrient deficiency, or some such bullshit.
If you've just undergone a major life change (or are in the middle of one) then it might just be that. New job, school, relationship, breakup, move, etc. might be the cause. Stressors will fuck you up for awhile and take a bit to pass after the event is more-or-less done. Depression can be triggered by a an event, but is more of a slow buildup over a long period, a lot of people can go months (or years) before they realize/accept something is wrong because of how it creeps in and builds up.

last_replies.com:
>>27724482
>I just wanted to be someone she/someone could like

This is a core feature of where your thinking is going astray. Stop defining yourself by how other people treat you. Stop defining yourself in terms of how you think other people want you to be. This is what's called an "external locus of control." As you have lived, you can NEVER hope to be everything to everyone and it has and will continue to destroy you tmentally.

Shift to an "internal locus of control." Embrace who you are, cultivate a sense of self that is willing to hear others out and take their opinions into consideration but NOT reflexively over value them nor use them as the sole measurement of who you are and how you live.

Also keep in mind anon, the vast majority of people are so caught up in their own bullshit that they really don't care about you. Realize that the overwhelming majority of the time, if someone feels "off" it has nothing to do with you. You aren't even a flashlight next to the sun of their narcissism.
